dialogues.text: (to Rory) Where’s the interpreter'’s file? Rory helps Chief Wu search through the files on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Why do you want us to look into this?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: If I carry an investigation off territory, I have to inform OSG and Secoord, and the OLA.  20.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: And the DPA. And the DGAACS.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: DPA, yes. The ACS folks can KMA.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: But OSG will...

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: Rory. Rory gestures an apology.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Is there a chance the UN will cancel the address?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: That’s up to the GA President. He can cancel at any point he deems the threat level too high. That’s the policy. Politically, he’d be hard put to cancel. The UN is its member states. One hundred-ninety- one of them. All equal.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Except in the Security Council.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: If the Republic of Matobo wants the cocksucker to speak, all they gotta do is ask. If other nations don’t like it, they take an early lunch. (re: the file search) I’m going nuts here, Rory. Chief Wu throws his hands up. Rory continues looking.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: You could ask State to rescind his entry visa.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: No, I couldn’t. I’m paid to protect Matobo’s interests however Matobo sees fit to define them. And I am expressly forbidden from soliciting American aid to impede those interests.  2i.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: (still looking) There’s a lot of sensitivity here to host-country influence. (standing) Got it. Rory holds two file copies, hands one to Chief Wu.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-bitch. Where was she?

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: On the credenza. Chief Wu’s face tells us he’s never heard of a credenza. hands Tobin a folder marked “Silvia Broome”.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: Should also be a transcript of her report in there.

dialogues.speaker: DOT
dialogues.text: What kind of assassin discusses a hit in a room full of microphones?

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: The kind who assumes that no one bugs a room full of microphones.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: What Rory’s trying not to say is we’re a den of spies and the GA is regularly swept.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: And has no security cameras.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: But why choose it for an actual assassination attempt? It’s the most secure room on the planet. Tobin is scanning SILVIA’S FILE PICTURE.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: You said you had veracity concerns?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: Ms. Broome is Matobean. Tobin looks up.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Three generations. But she has an American passport. Her father ran a rural hospital. He brought his wife to Beston for the daughter’s birth.

dialogues.speaker: DOT
dialogues.text: Land of the free, home of the epidural.

dialogues.speaker: RORY
dialogues.text: Her parents were killed by a land mine in 1989. They were driving in the Mukawa Mountains, mountains Zauwanie had mined to limit rebel activity. Tobin and Dot exchange a look. He hands Dot the file.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Okay. We’1l talk to her. Have you informed Matobo’s mission?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF WU
dialogues.text: Zuwanie’s security man has been in town for a week. (a beat) He’s hired Nils Lud. Tobin registers the name with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: The mercenary? Chief Wu nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NILS LUD (52) passes the African sculpture. Lud looks lik rust-belt insurance salesman: practical coat, thick glass a very large briefcase. Unaccustomed to cold, he never ta off his gloves. The only thing that suggests a military m is his slight limp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the sculpture, a TOUR GUIDE is leadi School Group as Workmen sweep up around it.

dialogues.speaker: TOUR GUIDE
dialogues.text: The Public Lobby is also used for temporary exhibitions. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOUR GUIDE (cont'd) This piece was given by the Republic of Matobo to commemorate their President’s visit a week from today. Against a wall behind the kids, Tobin and Dot stand benea “Smoking Discouraged” sign. Tobin touches Dot, indicates. Descending the walkway down from the GA balcony, Silvia w and. talks with.AUDREY.(29)...A.French.Interpreter-with.. Parisian accent and an impish manner.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Astiquer la baguette?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: There are people in France who actually refer to masturbation as “polishing the baguette”?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Of course. So? Our words for self- pleasing are cute, yours are violent. Jerk off. Whack off. Beat off. Give discipline to a monkey. Silvia laughs. Audrey’s performing.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You are very violent people. They come to the end of the walkway. Over by the wall, Tobin and Dot watch Silvia and Audrey c kiss good-bye. Silvia walks for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: She’s attractive.

dialogues.speaker: DOT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I hate her already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silvia walks out into the cold wind. Tobin and Dot are ri behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DOT
dialogues.text: Ms. Broome?  24. She stops. Dot and Tobin approach. Dot shows her badge an puts on a beauty-pageant smile. DoT Hi, there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garden is adjacent to the East River. The Queensboro Bridge sits majestically in front of it. The Secretariat rises stoically behind it. Tobin and Silvia sit on a bench. Dot stands out of earsho down the sidewalk, posted to insure privacy. The transcript of her previous interview blows in his han

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Tell me what you heard before the threat.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: An African man speaking French. I can’t remember what he was saying.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Only one man?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: But someone else had to be talking. (off the transcript) “Don’t worry, Edmond Zuwanie will die in this room.” He’s responding to someone.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: He was at one of the delegates’ tables, a mic was open nearby; the other person may have been farther from the mic. He watches her a few an uneasy moments.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What’s diplomat French?  25.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Diplomats learn French as protocol, their word choice can be unusual. A native speaker would’ve said hall, salle, not room, chambre.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: But his accent was African? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Matobean?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: My instinct is to say Sub-Saharan African, yes, but that could be because it’s familiar.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: You didn’t hesitate reporting him?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I thought about it. When the booth light came on, he stopped talking. I think he saw me. Tobin makes a face calculated to show concern.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: But I didn’t see him.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t know that. He lets her consider the implications for a few seconds a scans the transcript. Finally, he closes her folder. He smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Is Zuwanie as bad everyone makes him out to be?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Are you fishing to find out how T feel about him?

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. 26.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I'd like to see him trapped beneath twisted metal for six hours, forced to watch his wife bleed to death.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: And you weren’t tempted to keep quiet, let him take his chances?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I’m not very good at being cynical.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: (re: the UN) It means look around. Why do you think I’m sitting here? Somewhere there’s a war. In a place you can’t pronounce. For reasons you can’t understand. Our job is to stop it. It’s hard work. Complex. Boring. Bureaucratic. You have to believe in it. You have to believe rules matter. You have to believe words are enough to change things.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Words do change things, they tell us where to point the guns. He may be kidding, but she doesn’t smile. He watches her. wants her to feel uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: It's cold.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: That’s all for now. She stands.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: You don’t believe much in politics, do you?  27.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: I’ve stood on too many podiums. If you ask me, somewhere on the road to power there’s a great big neon sign. It says, “If you made it this far, you don’t deserve to be here.” Again, she doesn’t smile. She starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: One more question. (he makes her wait) Maybe you can’t remember a second voice because there was never any one down there to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: That’s not a question.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Are you lying?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: No. Silvia holds his eyes for a moment - and then walks away. Tobin watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JON (28) hands Tobin a thick folder with a CIA seal.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Edmond Zuwanie. They walk on. Jon is African-American and has that hipste grad-student-in-global-politics-vibe - this guy has smoke hash in some very remote places.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: (re: the folder) Is this classified?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Not if you have a subscription to “The Economist”. He's leading Tobin through a research bull pen. It’s a ju maze of white geeks and Africans. Cubicles are decorated bright flags, African barber “do” boards, soccer memorabi  28.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Zuwanie’s killed a fifty thousand ethnic Ku in six years. Opposition leader is this McGili-educated novelist named Kuman-Kuman; he’s in hiding. No one’s seen the guy in almost a month. Here... Jon gestures to a cubicle. They look in on an AFRICAN. SO FAN watching a game on a small monitor. Jon grabs a book the Fan’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Nigeria versus Norway. I’ve seen it. Boring.

dialogues.speaker: SOCCER FAN
dialogues.text: Black men chasing white men while thousands cheer is never boring. The Fan dismisses them with a chuckle and a wave. His lef arm has been amputated above the elbow.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Zuwanie? He nods and hands Tobin the book.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Believe me, you don’t want to jump a bullet for this guy. CLOSE on the book’s cover: “The Casual Dead” by Edgar Suk Kuman-Kuman.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did you have anything on Silvia Broome?

dialogues.speaker: JON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nope. Jon and Tobin continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Who would have a reason for hitting Zuwanie inside the UN?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: No one. He’s got you, the UN Police and Nils Lud all protecting him. I Doesn’t make sense. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JON (cont'd) Especially since his domestic security force is mostly corrupt relatives; you could take him out with a potato peeler and a long weekend.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s some anti-UN group?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: Could be the AFP. African Freedom Party. Their favorite rant is how the UN has become a puppet of the imperialist North.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Where do they stand on Zuwanie?

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: They hate him. He’s given self-rule a bad name. Jon stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: JON
dialogues.text: These are serious people, Tobin. If the AFP is involved, they’1l want this to go down in front of cameras - and they’1l1 have no intention of getting out alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

POV FROM ACROSS THE STREET: Their laughter and voices fog the cold night air. Different languages. None quite coher The others seem to want Silvia to go with them. She decli Silvia walks up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

And the footsteps of someone behind her.  30. She looks back to see a YOUNG BLACK MAN IN A SUIT. He mov closer and closer. He comes in step twenty feet behind he And stays there. Their steps echo like heartbeats in sync He reaches into his suit. And pulls out a vibrating cell. checks the caller ID, answers in an American accent...

dialogues.text: You’ re way too close. the Suit changes pace. This is AGENT DOUG SAMPLE (26).

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Fine, I guess. My boss is getting to be a pain the ass. Dot disconnects and watches Doug follow Silvia up the Ave

dialogues.text: Doug yawns as he eats with AGENT MOHAMMAD SAID (28), a cr Arab-American. They share the New York Post. Both look li you'd expect from two guys wearing yesterday's clothes. D holds up a paper section.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Sports?

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMAD
dialogues.text: I’m not done yet. Tobin suddenly plops down beside them. Fresh-faced. Vigor

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What’s she reading? POV THROUGH THE WINDOW: Silvia sits in a coffee house acr the street, reading while she eats breakfast. He can only her back and part of her face.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Newspapers. In five different languages. Back on the boys.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMAD
dialogues.text: She got up at six to go jogging.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: And she made three cell calls and received one. It sounded like...

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMAD
dialogues.text: It was Hebrew.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Any idea what she said, Mohammed?  32.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMAD
dialogues.text: I didn’t exactly go to Hebrew school. Tobin gives him a smile, stands.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Okay. Follow her until she goes into the UN, then clock out. Tobin exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tobin comes out of the diner, careful not to be seen by Silvia. He checks his watch and hurries down the street. A GREEK TOURIST passes him talking into a cell phone...

dialogues.speaker: GREEK TOURIST
dialogues.text: Eepahrhee kahnaynah ahloh mayrohs sahfteen teen pohlee g-eeah? Tobin stops in the cold. His eyes follow the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Department of Homeland Security seal woven in the carpe Shari gossips with the Receptionist at the front desk as Tobin enters in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Zuwanie’s Advance Man is in your office.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What if she heard one voice because he was on a cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Right. Who? He ignores the question. They move into the cube farm.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Contact the security liaisons for the phone companies. Ask for a list of cell calls made or received in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday night - all calls between ten and eleven.  33.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Then get a list of all the African nationals and immigrants working at the United Nations, or UN missions, diplomats and staff.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Rory Robb. Cross check the lists. I need a name and address for every male African at the UN who used a cell during that hour.

dialogues.speaker: SHARI
dialogues.text: Isn’t this racial profiling? He hurries toward his office. She calls after him... TOBIN’S ASSISTANT (cont’ d) Tell me we have a computer program that does the cross-checking. INT. TOBIN’S OFFICE - DAY The field office is a few blocks from the UN; the Secreta can be seen through Tobin’s window. Nils Lud is in a chair holding “The Casual Dead”. Dot sit the desk. Tobin enters.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Mr. Lud. (they shake hands) How’s the mercenary life?

dialogues.speaker: NILS LUD
dialogues.text: Blood, diamonds and mosquitos are always the same. Nils Lud has a strong Afrikaner accent and a wry smile. T goes and sits behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: NILS LUD
dialogues.text: We’re a public company now. I’ve have shares in my case if you are interested.  34.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: I bet you do. Tobin’s chuckle tells us he detests this man.

dialogues.speaker: NILS LUD
dialogues.text: There is a small problem.

dialogues.speaker: DOT
dialogues.text: Silvia Broome.

dialogues.speaker: NILS LUD
dialogues.text: What do you know about her?

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Not enough.

dialogues.speaker: NILS LUD
dialogues.text: From 1996 to 1998, Miss Broome was sexually involved with a young man from Matobo. A graduate student in Canada. She and this man also lived together for one year in New York. Miscegenation is common with White Africans.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What’s your point, Nils? Lud holds up the jacket photo on the back of “The Casual Dead”.

dialogues.speaker: NILS LUD
dialogues.text: The man was Edgar Sukru Kuman- Kuman. Tobin looks at Dot. She nods. He gets up and goes to the window. The Secretariat is visible beneath snow clouds. His fury grows.

dialogues.speaker: NILS LUD
dialogues.text: We are requesting you place her in protective custody during President Zawanie’s visit. And I wish to talk to her. Lud puts an official-looking letter on Tobin’s desk. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DOT
dialogues.text: Tobin?  35.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: No, I’1l do it. Nils Lud gestures acquiescence with a false grin. Cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silvia and her INDIAN DATE exit a resturant, laughing. Sh stops as she sees Tobin across the street. Snow flakes on shoulders suggest he’s been waiting a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I should talk to this guy.

dialogues.speaker: THE DATE
dialogues.text: You sure? She nods. He’s surprised that his date is ending abruptly confused as just how to respond. Tobin simply watches.

dialogues.speaker: THE DATE
dialogues.text: Right. Well. I guess... She takes control.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Thank you. She kisses him on the lips. Holding it just long enough s doesn’t seem perfunctory.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: It's okay. Call me. He nods and moves off, shooting a glance at his sudden ri Tobin makes Silvia come to him. She stands in the middle the street and starts where they left off...

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I bet you don’t vote, either.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: And risk jury duty?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: I thought I’d walk you home.  36. She pretends it’s offer she can refuse. Nods. She makes h way onto the sidewalk. They walk a few uncomfortable step Tobin looks up at flurries coming into the light...

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Do you miss Africa?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Sometimes. I miss friends. I miss certain things.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: The rush of hot air when you get off the plane. Dogs everywhere. The way the night smells like smoke.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What don’t you miss?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Baboons, the meanest animals on the planet. Warm Cokes. Poverty. Ganja- smelling men with AK47s. It’s hard to miss bodies hanging on telephone poles. They walk a moment in silence.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Sorry, I shouldn’t talk that way. Most people assume White Africans are racists.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Are they?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: My grandparents were. But my dad’s preferred form of rebellion was white guilt. I had to hide Madonna albums in Bob Marley covers.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Bet he would have loved Edgar. She stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: What do you want from me, Agent Keller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I always tell the truth...

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Don’t sell me your nobility, I’ve heard..that..one. She walks on.

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Edgar’s a painful subject.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What did he tell you to do?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What did he tell you to do?!

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I heard you.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: He won’t talk to me! A beat. They wait while a couple passes.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Because you left him?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: He left me.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I’m white.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: When did you hear from him last?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Five years ago.  38.

dialogues.speaker: TOBIN
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: The unabridged version? (sarcastically) Dear Silvia. Good-bye. At your Side, I will never be more than a statement. At my. side,..you.will never be more than metaphor of colonialism. I'm going back to Africa. Sincerely, Edgar. A beat. Her tone softens...

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: I wish he would ask for help. I’ve wasted years waiting for that call. She waits a moment. Then...

dialogues.speaker: SILVIA
dialogues.text: Good-night.
